segments.text: Joseph's wife died in mid-November, just as the sweet peas were in full bloom, surrounding all the walls of the pink house.
Soon they would wither and die as well.
No one knew she wasn't really his wife, and it didn't matter, for she was his lady.
No one knew she was several good years older than he was.
It seemed the entire town touching the sea marched in a long line behind them, father and daughter, to the old sanitary in Migdal, Ashkelon.
At the entrance, they paused to embrace the Haddad family, who had just finished burying the family patriarch.
A small town, everyone knows everyone.
Only then did they continue along the path to the pre-Doug grave.
Joseph walked closely with his daughter, a skinny girl with long hair covering part of her profile, holding her hand tightly, perhaps to strengthen her, perhaps to find strength himself.
all the way into the cemetery, the girl glanced at the stretcher upon which her mother lay.
What remained of her?
For a moment, a glimmer of thought arose that she seemed small like a child.
She had never been to a funeral before, and had no idea that this was how a body was wrapped, the shape evident, especially when the deceased was so thin and frail.
Occasionally, she sneaked a look at Joseph, trying to discern what lay beneath his set expression.
He was pale, his square chin taut, eyes staring straight ahead.
At one point, he caught her gaze, released her hand, and reached to gently stroke her head for just a moment.
Then, his hand was again gripping hers tightly, almost causing pain.
In her other hand, she held a large wreath of sweet pea flowers, which she had either picked or plucked shortly before they left the house.
These were mama's flowers, and the ritual of planting them and waiting for their bloom each year before winter brought her mother great joy.
She plucked them quickly, stem by stem, full of blooms in peak, until there was no room left in her hand, and a large bouquet of pink and purple filled her grasp.
Only then did she feel at ease.
This clucking came from deep within her, feeling it was right and fitting, wanting to cover her mother with her flowers, before being covered with dirt.
Now she watched as the men gently lowered the wrapped body into the grave, and in a moment they would lift shovels and throw the soil they had piled beside, with two quick steps.
She reached them, approached the grave's opening, and scattered the flowers all over her, side to side.
Not above the grave, but inside it.
She wanted her to be buried with her flowers, with their color, with their scent.
Silence descended on the cemetery.
Joseph looked at her in amazement without a word.
Everyone around was silent.
Even the clergy were speechless.
It touched their hearts, nearly tore their hearts.
To see this child girl, not yet sixteen, insist on sending her mother on her way, wrapped in the flowers she so loved, flowers she had sewn with her hands each year before winter.
She watched the men thrust the shovels into the pile of earth, tossing it over her mother, hearing the thud of the spade in the soil.
again and again, and with each thud, her body contracted, and she bit her lips, holding back the sob that wished to erupt from within, feeling as though the soil was being thrown over her own body.
Slowly, it piled up until it became a small mound with a wooden sign stabbed into it, on which was written in black marker, Lucia Friedman.
That wasn't even her name, and no one knew.
